title: Theme Introduction
segmentation: Cybersecurity, well, this is the topic that I'm going to chair a discussion on this afternoon and hopefully it'll get involved and and share your experiences.

There's a lot more insight than than we at the table here can provide to you, but I'm I'm going to just start giving a little overview of some perceptions and thoughts that I have had in considering this topic over the last number of weeks.
And then I'll introduce my my colleagues to make their.
Expert contributions as well.

So I'm going to look at this from the point of view of insider threats, and I think it's very important to note that it's not about the 98% you catch, but it's about the 2% you miss when you're talking about about security of any type.
It's the breaches, and the weakness that we're looking for, and that we're refering to, so I'm going to start talking or just mention.
Ning.
A breach of data.
JPMorgan data breach back in 2414.
I beg your pardon.

On a particular day in the springtime, some hackers stole the login credentials of a JPMorgan employee, and they were able to access the server, and this is despite I'm just going to start my timer here.

Keep in mind that I'm this is, despite the fact that the company had a practice of using a two factor authentication on most of its systems, and this of course uses the you know, some static passwords alongside a one time access generated by some physical hardware device or or mobile app.
But the JP Morgan team apparently neglected to deploy this system on at least one of the company's many servers, leading to the absence of that security layer and enabling the attack to take place.
And following this intrusion, the attackers were eventually able to gain access to more than 90 servers at the bank.
Four employees were arrested and it turned out that the data breach compromised the personal information of 83 million individuals and small businesses in the summer of 2014.

The breach was even wider than that, and it was later on in the summer on an external website that was set up for a charitable race, which was sponsored by JP Morgan that they were able to determine that the attackers had had access to other systems for many months.
So I suppose what this story does is it echoes the warnings of security experts over the years that the breach of a single server or employee computer can put an entire network.
At risk.
So.
Insider threats, I suppose.
When we're looking at systems and we're looking at security, what we've got to consider are where are the access points and where are the weaknesses in the armor that there's?
A perception is around, and minding and and keeping safe all of these servers where the information is stored.

Now, a company can often detect or control when an outsider or a non employee tries to access company data either physically or electronically and can mitigate the threat of of some data or information being stolen.
However, it's much more difficult to detect the thief who is an insider.
The employee who has legitimate access.
And that employee are insider may steal the data for a number of reasons.
It could be for personal gain, or they may actually be a spy and someone who is stealing the data or company information in order to benefit another organization.
And that's a point that's been made by the FBI.
There are many different are number of different types of insiders who can cause a thresh.
The negligent insider, who is careless, doesn't doesn't follow company policy etc.
Anne.
But I think more sinister is the malicious insider, and I think considering that is is the key.

Maybe to looking are too considering some ways of mitigating damage that might be caused by this kind of threat and malicious, malicious insider threat to an organization could be from a current or former employee, could be a contractor or another business partner who has authorized access to the network, and I think that's really important.
It's the person who has the.
Authorized they're not breaking any rules or any protocols they have authorized, but they either exceed their authorization or misuse.
The access in a manner that negatively affects the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of the company's information.
So.
Just.
Considering what the motivations might be for some of the the personal motivations for some of the intra insider threatening people or personnel.
So you can see here on this mind map that personal factors are wide and varied and they can be anything from you know, greed or financial need.

There might be a feeling that really there's a justification in having some of the great wealth that an organization has access to could be angered or revenge where there's an employee who's disgruntled, disgruntled employee might also embark on some blackmail and that might be another motivation divided loyalties, approval seeking problems at work.
All sorts of things around job satisfaction not being recognized for the contribution that they're making.
You know, perhaps a pending layoff.
All sorts of issues that make a person feel insecure.
Personal intrinsic internal to the person.
Things like their ideology and maybe their their view about the position of the type of industry in society.
They type that the industry that they are working in thrill seeking their own self esteem and self image and perhaps raising their own profile by having access to information or to data.

As well as personal personal problems, you know family problems, personal problems, all of these are possible potential motivators, and considering these and looking at them, it makes one think that perhaps in preventing this type of threat to an organization, maybe it's something as simple as having good quality employer employee relations.
Or, you know, focusing on positive H or practices and policies as much as.
Looking at the strength of the systems that are trying to guarantee the the security.
There are also organizational factors and there is there are very specific motivators for for organizational.

Access I suppose to security and breaches emanating from that that that area, so the ease of access to systems unrefined policy regarding working from home bring your own device remote access some of these things are becoming very common common practice, but the the organization doesn't always take account of how they could be managed and how the security could be enhanced around these these types of.
Facilities I suppose that are made available to staff.

The more you, the more open systems become, the more you trust staff, the more you have to ensure that there is good governance around how they manage that trust and the systems that that put boundaries around what they what they can manage to to access.
I think again, good management is the way to to reduce the threat of some of these elements and to reduce these motivations for for the organizational aspect of threats to security.
And again, prevention is better than cure if we can get to that point.

I'm going to just look at a case in point because we can talk about having good practice and having you know encryption and having passwords and access details and authorization codes and details and logins kept secure and.
And and in the right hands.
But this is a screenshot from a Sony server, and it was adapted from an article in Gizmodo, and it's a classic example of weak security practices.
So you can see that the the IT team stored their most sensitive password data in a folder under the label passwords, so you know you might say.
How clever is that?
But of course it didn't take long for anybody with view of this to be able to figure out.
How to access various secure and private data from the from the pop is handed to them on a plate in terms of access and information for accessing what should have been secure data.
I mean, who needs encrypt, encryption or security?
You know?

I mean, you know we would expect that people that I T professionals who are working in these kinds of areas you know would have a little bit more than you know, elementary school level appreciation of security, you know?
So yeah, sure, you know a folder with the name, name, passwords, or you know, computer passwords dot XLS, contact list and passwords credential passwords, you know, accounts passwords.
You know, it's incredible really that that in a very large Corporation that this kind of setup would be in place.
But it's it's true, it happened and it's really lazy and unimaginative, and.
Not a very good example of governance and business process in order.
If there's a concern about security.
So.
Insider activities are all behavioral.
So they're to do with the person who is the attacker.
Technology can't detect insider threats.
The insider who causes a threat to the data or security of systems in an organization is likely to be a respectable person, liked by colleagues and management.
They are likely to be smart with a detailed understanding of business process and workings.
They're likely to be trustworthy or have a perception of being trustworthy, which has been built up overtime.
Their access to the systems is likely to be unfettered.
They are likely to be astute and shrewd.
Probably a model employee and the least suspected person.
You know, among the cohort of people who might potentially have access.
So.
Some of these these images on this slide.
Now they are there from the CIO Insight Magazine and I have the the URL to this data that supports them.
If anybody is interested.
So who are the insiders?
Well, managers apparently posed the greatest threat at 59%, according to respondents in the CIO Insight Magazine survey, followed closely by contractors and consultants at 48% and 46%.
And 30% of respondents to this survey said that their organization lacks appropriate controls to prevent insider hacks.
23% or not sure, but 47% said they do that they do have appropriate controls.
So there's not.
There isn't an accurate perception, that of the problem or the scale of the problem, or that the problem exists.
And the risky users, the top five again just to summarize, risky users are privileged users are managers, 59% contractors, consultants and temporary workers, and then regular employees.
At 46% ITA administrators and staff, I found that one actually quite quite interesting that the risk associated with my team managers and staff and then third party service providers.
But even though the range there goes from 59% down to.
To 41% for internal people.
They're quite quite close.
There's a very high percentage of all of those categories of people are risky users of systems, and I think that's really something to to bear in mind and to to be cognizant of.
And then these are just as I come to the end of this introduction.
These are just a couple of headlines on insider threats which have appeared in various publications so far in 2015.
So it says 1/3 of employees would sell corporate information for the right price.
An 93% of companies face inside your threat security risks.
58% of information security incidents are attributed to insider insider threat.
You know 92% of healthcare IT administrators, fear insider threats.
There's another figure and I haven't got it to hand, but it's a very high number of patients in the US are unhappy about the security of their personal health data.
That's a very of great relevance to us in Ireland at the moment.
Where there's.

We've recently introduced a National Health identifier and there's a lot of work underway at the moment to prepare for the introduction of an electronic health record system across the board for Irish citizens.

Hackers are selling your data on the darkweb for only $1, but there's a lot of a lot more value and and there's a lot more money than that being being garnered for from people for the sale of personal data.
So.
Just.
To say that 2015 has witnessed Enterprise is starting to adopt devices that communicate with each other.
And of course, this is what we're calling the Internet of Things.

And according to Gartner 4.9 billion connected things will be in use by next year, and that's an increase of 30% from 2014, so the security issues surrounding the Internet of Things will also gain traction due to the fact that those devices are not inherently secure, which could potentially lead to.
Device hacks are data leakages.
So organizations will increasingly be concerned with who manages and operates these devices and technology approaches to manage the security and the risk of the Internet of Things.
But critically, it's The Who is the person.

It's the people, and I think as as we listen to more presentations on this topic, I think our discussion might look at during the course of this at the extent to which it is the people, or it is the technology which can ensure us or give us the best.
Assurance of of Security for systems and for data.

So the topic for today is of the utmost importance and the main are a significant problem that we have to address is the actual recognition that a problem exists or that it there is a concern around people and the human element of maintaining security.
So that's my little bit and my introduction.
So to develop the theme somewhat, I'm going to introduce the second speaker now.
And Andrea Simmons, who is an independent consultant who is with us today from the UK.

Although she's an Irish lady, is going to speak about cyber threats hiding in plain sight now, Andrea is going to give you a little introduction to herself and her background before she started to make her presentation.
So thank you very much.
